name: Energy and Potential Difference
what: This subtopic covers how electrical energy is created through charge separation, how potential difference relates to energy per unit charge, and how to measure and calculate energy in circuits.
why: Understanding potential difference explains how batteries and power supplies provide energy to circuits. This knowledge is essential for designing everything from phone chargers to electric vehicles.

items.title: I can explain that separating charges creates potential difference and requires energy input
items.what: When positive and negative charges are separated, electrical potential energy is stored. Batteries use chemical reactions to separate charges, while generators use kinetic energy.
items.why: Understanding charge separation explains how all electrical energy sources work, from simple batteries to solar panels and power stations.
items.example: In a 9 V battery, chemical reactions separate positive and negative charges to the two terminals. This separation stores energy that can do 9 joules of work for every coulomb of charge that flows through a circuit.

items.title: I can define potential difference as energy per unit charge and apply V = E/Q
items.what: Potential difference (V) is the energy (E) transferred per coulomb of charge (Q). It is measured in volts, where 1 V = 1 J/C. The formula can be rearranged to E = QV.
items.why: This relationship shows that both the amount of charge and the potential difference determine the total energy transferred in a circuit.
items.example: A 12 V car battery supplies 12 joules of energy for every coulomb of charge. If 500 C flows through the circuit, the total energy supplied is E = QV = 500 Ã— 12 = 6000 J.

items.title: I can apply E = VIt to calculate electrical energy in a circuit
items.what: Combining V = E/Q with I = Q/t gives E = VIt. This formula calculates the energy transferred when current I flows through a potential difference V for time t.
items.why: This formula is practical because V and I can be measured directly with meters, making it easy to calculate energy consumption of appliances.
items.example: A phone charger operates at 5 V with 2 A current for 2 hours (7200 s). The energy delivered is E = VIt = 5 Ã— 2 Ã— 7200 = 72,000 J = 72 kJ.

items.title: I can use a voltmeter correctly to measure potential difference
items.what: A voltmeter measures potential difference in volts and must be connected in parallel across a component. It compares the energy per charge entering and leaving the component.
items.why: Measuring potential difference tells us how much energy each coulomb of charge transfers to or from a component, which is essential for circuit analysis.
items.example: To measure the potential difference across a light bulb, connect the voltmeter leads to either side of the bulb without breaking the circuit. A reading of 6 V means each coulomb loses 6 J of energy in the bulb.

items.title: I can distinguish between the positioning of an ammeter (series) and voltmeter (parallel)
items.what: Ammeters go in series because they must measure all charge flowing through. Voltmeters go in parallel because they compare energy at two points without interrupting current flow.
items.why: Incorrect meter placement gives wrong readings and can damage meters. Understanding why each meter is placed differently helps avoid these errors.
items.example: To test a light bulb circuit: break the circuit and insert the ammeter so all current flows through it (series). Connect the voltmeter across the bulb without breaking the circuit (parallel).

items.title: I can use analogies to explain potential difference and energy transfer in circuits
items.what: The bowling ball analogy shows balls gaining gravitational potential energy when lifted (like charge gaining electrical energy from a battery) and losing it when falling through liquid (like energy transfer in components).
items.why: Gravitational analogies help visualise the abstract concept of electrical potential energy, making it easier to understand how energy flows in circuits.
items.example: In the waterfall analogy, water height represents potential difference. A 12 m waterfall (12 V battery) gives each kilogram of water (coulomb of charge) 12 times more energy than a 1 m waterfall (1 V battery).
